Yes, I believe the correct translation of the Chinese text "一颗子弹报销一个敌人" is "One bullet reimburses one enemy".

To explain why I think this is the correct translation, let's break down the Chinese text. "一颗子弹" can be translated to "one bullet". "报销" can be translated to "reimburse" or "settle accounts". "一个敌人" can be translated to "one enemy". 

Putting it all together, the sentence can be translated as "One bullet reimburses/settles accounts for one enemy." This translation accurately conveys the meaning of the original Chinese text as it describes how one bullet is enough to take out one enemy. Additionally, the use of "reimburse" in this translation suggests a sort of exchange or debt being paid, which fits with the context of the original text suggesting an act of violence.

The word "报销" is often used in the military context to indicate the successful elimination of an enemy in battle. 

Therefore, when translated as "One bullet eliminates one enemy", it accurately conveys the idea that one single bullet can be powerful enough to take out an enemy, while also fitting with the context of violence and warfare implied in the original text.
